components.name: panel
components.title: Vue Panel Component
components.description: Panel is a grouping component providing with content toggle feature.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Toggleable panels use a content toggle button at the header that has aria-controls to define the id of the content section along with aria-expanded for the visibility state. The value to read the button defaults to the value of the header property and can be customized by defining an aria-label or aria-labelledby via the toggleButtonProps property. The content uses region , defines an id that matches the aria-controls of the content toggle button and aria-labelledby referring to the id of the header. Content Toggle Button Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the next the focusable element in the page tab sequence. shift + tab Moves focus to the previous the focusable element in the page tab sequence. enter Toggles the visibility of the content. space Toggles the visibility of the content.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: A simple Panel is created with a header property along with the content as children.

components.name: panelmenu
components.title: Vue PanelMenu Component
components.description: PanelMenu is a hybrid of accordion-tree components.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Accordion header elements have a button role, an aria-label defined using the label property of the menuitem model and aria-controls to define the id of the content section along with aria-expanded for the visibility state. The content of an accordion panel uses region role, defines an id that matches the aria-controls of the header and aria-labelledby referring to the id of the header. The tree elements has a tree as the role and each menu item has a treeitem role along with aria-label and aria-expanded attributes. The container element of a treenode has the group role. The aria-setsize , aria-posinset and aria-level attributes are calculated implicitly and added to each treeitem. Header Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the next the focusable element in the page tab sequence. shift + tab Moves focus to the previous the focusable element in the page tab sequence. enter Toggles the visibility of the content. space Toggles the visibility of the content. down arrow Moves focus to the next header. If focus is on the last header, moves focus to the first header. up arrow Moves focus to the previous header. If focus is on the first header, moves focus to the last header. home Moves focus to the first header. end Moves focus to the last header.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: PanelMenu requires a collection of menuitems as its model .

examples.basic: <PanelMenu :model="items" />

sections.label: Command
sections.description: The command property defines the callback to run when an item is activated by click or a key event.

examples.basic:
<PanelMenu :model="items" />
<Toast />

sections.label: Controlled
sections.description: If the menuitem has a key defined, PanelMenu state can be controlled programmatically with the expandedKeys property that defines the keys that are expanded. This property is a Map instance whose key is the key of a node and value is a boolean.

examples.basic:
<Button type="button" label="Toggle All" text @click="toggleAll" />
<PanelMenu v-model:expandedKeys="expandedKeys" :model="items" />
import PanelMenu from 'primevue/panelmenu';

sections.label: Multiple
sections.description: Only one root menuitem at a time can be active by default, enabling multiple property changes this behavior to allow multiple root menuitems.

examples.basic: <PanelMenu :model="items" multiple />

sections.label: Router
sections.description: Items with navigation are defined with templating to be able to use a router link component, an external link or programmatic navigation.

sections.label: Template
sections.description: PanelMenu offers item customization with the item template that receives the menuitem instance from the model as a parameter.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Each component has a special pt property to define an object with keys corresponding to the available DOM elements. Each value can either be a string, an object or a function that returns a string or an object to define the arbitrary properties to apply to the element such as styling, aria, data-* or custom attributes. If the value is a string or a function that returns a string, it is considered as a class definition and added to the class attribute of the element. Every component documentation has a dedicated section to document the available section names exposed via PT. Most common usage of pt is styling and customization. The class and style properties support the exact syntax of the corresponding Vue bindings like arrays, objects and conditionals. Example below styles an unstyled Panel component with Tailwind CSS library.

sections.label: Custom CSS
sections.description: The global property has a css option to define custom css that belongs to a global pt configuration. Common use case of this feature is defining global styles and animations related to the pass through configuration.

sections.label: Declarative
sections.description: The declarative syntax provides an alternative to the programmatic syntax. The attributes that start with pt are interpreted differently by the component based on the format below. An IDE extension is also being planned to autocomplete the values for better developer experience in the future. Here is another example using both syntax alternatives for the same options.

sections.label: Global
sections.description: Defines the shared pass through properties per component type. For example, with the configuration below all panel headers have the bg-primary style class and all autocomplete components have a fixed width. These settings can be overridden by a particular component as components pt property has higher precedence over global pt .

sections.label: Introduction
sections.description: In traditional 3rd party UI libraries, users are limited to the API provided by component author. This API commonly consists of props, events and slots. Whenever a requirement emerges for a new customization option in the API, the component author needs to develop and publish it with a new release. Vision of PrimeTek is Your components, not ours . The pass through feature is a key element to implement this vision by exposing the component internals in order to apply arbitrary attributes and listeners to the DOM elements. The primary advantage of this approach is that it frees you from being restricted by the main component API. We recommend considering the pass-through feature whenever you need to tailor a component that lacks a built-in feature for your specific requirement. Two videos are available at PrimeTV youtube channel, first one is an introduction and second one covers a unique case that is solved by the pass-through.

sections.label: Lifecycle
sections.description: Lifecycle hooks of components are exposed as pass through using the hooks property so that callback functions can be registered. Available callbacks are onBeforeCreate , onCreated , onBeforeUpdate , onUpdated , onBeforeMount , onMounted , onBeforeUnmount and onUnmounted . Refer to the Vue.js documentation for detailed information about lifecycle hooks.

examples.basic:
<Panel header="Header" :pt="panelPT">
    Content
</Panel>

sections.label: PC Prefix
sections.description: Section names prefixed with pc denote PrimeVue components, distinguishing them from standard DOM elements and indicating the necessity for a nested structure. For example, the "badge" section is identified as pcBadge because the button component incorporates the badge component internally.

sections.label: UsePassThrough
sections.description: An existing pass through configuration is customized with the usePassThrough utility. The first parameter is the object to customize, the second parameter is the customizations and the final parameter is the merge strategy. The mergeSections defines whether the sections from the main configuration gets added and the mergeProps controls whether to override or merge the defined props. Defaults are true for mergeSections and false for mergeProps .

components.name: password
components.title: Vue Password Component
components.description: Password displays strength indicator for password fields.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Value to describe the component can either be provided via label tag combined with id prop or using aria-labelledby , aria-label props. Screen reader is notified about the changes to the strength of the password using a section that has aria-live while typing. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the input. escape Hides the strength meter if open.

examples.basic: Password

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Password is used with the v-model property for two-way value binding.

examples.basic: <Password v-model="value" :feedback="false" />

sections.label: Clear Icon
sections.description: When showClear is enabled, a clear icon is added to reset the Password.

examples.basic: <Password v-model="value" :feedback="false" showClear inputClass="w-56" />

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, the element cannot be edited and focused.

examples.basic: <Password disabled placeholder="Disabled" />

sections.label: Filled
sections.description: Specify the variant property as filled to display the component with a higher visual emphasis than the default outlined style.

examples.basic: <Password v-model="value" :feedback="false" variant="filled" />

sections.label: Float Label
sections.description: A floating label appears on top of the input field when focused. Visit FloatLabel documentation for more information.

examples.basic:
<FloatLabel>
    <Password v-model="value1" inputId="over_label" />
    <label for="over_label">Over Label</label>
</FloatLabel>

<FloatLabel variant="in">
    <Password v-model="value2" inputId="in_label" variant="filled" />
    <label for="in_label">In Label</label>
</FloatLabel>

<FloatLabel variant="on">
    <Password v-model="value3" inputId="on_label" />
    <label for="on_label">On Label</label>
</FloatLabel>

sections.label: Fluid
sections.description: The fluid prop makes the component take up the full width of its container when set to true.

examples.basic: <Password v-model="value" :feedback="false" fluid />

sections.label: Forms
sections.description: InputText is used with the v-model property.

sections.label: Ifta Label
sections.description: IftaLabel is used to create infield top aligned labels. Visit IftaLabel documentation for more information.

examples.basic:
<IftaLabel>
    <Password v-model="value" inputId="password" variant="filled" />
    <label for="password">Password</label>
</IftaLabel>
import Password from 'primevue/password';

sections.label: Invalid
sections.description: Invalid state is displayed using the invalid prop to indicate a failed validation. You can use this style when integrating with form validation libraries.

examples.basic:
<Password v-model="value1" :invalid="!value1" placeholder="Password" />
<Password v-model="value2" :invalid="!value2" variant="filled" placeholder="Password" />

sections.label: Locale
sections.description: Labels are translated at component level by promptLabel , weakLabel , mediumLabel and strongLabel properties. In order to apply global translations for all Password components in the application, refer to the locale .

examples.basic: <Password v-model="value" promptLabel="Choose a password" weakLabel="Too simple" mediumLabel="Average complexity" strongLabel="Complex password" />

sections.label: Meter
sections.description: Strength meter is displayed as a popup while a value is being entered.

examples.basic: <Password v-model="value" />

sections.label: Sizes
sections.description: Password provides small and large sizes as alternatives to the base.

sections.label: Template
sections.description: 3 slots are included to customize the overlay. These are header , content and footer . Note that content overrides the default meter.

sections.label: ToggleMask
sections.description: When toggleMask is present, an icon is displayed to show the value as plain text.

examples.basic: <Password v-model="value" toggleMask />

props.name: aria-activedescendant
props.description: Identifies the currently active element when DOM focus is on a composite widget, textbox, group, or application.

props.name: aria-atomic
props.description: Indicates whether assistive technologies will present all, or only parts of, the changed region based on the change notifications defined by the aria-relevant attribute.

props.name: aria-autocomplete
props.description:
Indicates whether inputting text could trigger display of one or more predictions of the user's intended value for an input and specifies how predictions would be
presented if they are made.

props.name: aria-busy
props.description: Indicates an element is being modified and that assistive technologies MAY want to wait until the modifications are complete before exposing them to the user.

props.name: aria-checked
props.description: Indicates the current "checked" state of checkboxes, radio buttons, and other widgets.

props.name: aria-colcount
props.description: Defines the total number of columns in a table, grid, or treegrid.

props.name: aria-colindex
props.description: Defines an element's column index or position with respect to the total number of columns within a table, grid, or treegrid.

props.name: aria-colspan
props.description: Defines the number of columns spanned by a cell or gridcell within a table, grid, or treegrid.

props.name: aria-controls
props.description: Identifies the element (or elements) whose contents or presence are controlled by the current element.

props.name: aria-current
props.description: Indicates the element that represents the current item within a container or set of related elements.

props.name: aria-describedby
props.description: Identifies the element (or elements) that describes the object.

props.name: aria-details
props.description: Identifies the element that provides a detailed, extended description for the object.

props.name: aria-disabled
props.description: Indicates that the element is perceivable but disabled, so it is not editable or otherwise operable.

props.name: aria-dropeffect
props.description: Indicates what functions can be performed when a dragged object is released on the drop target.

props.name: aria-errormessage
props.description: Identifies the element that provides an error message for the object.

props.name: aria-expanded
props.description: Indicates whether the element, or another grouping element it controls, is currently expanded or collapsed.

props.name: aria-flowto
props.description:
Identifies the next element (or elements) in an alternate reading order of content which, at the user's discretion,
allows assistive technology to override the general default of reading in document source order.

props.name: aria-grabbed
props.description: Indicates an element's "grabbed" state in a drag-and-drop operation.

props.name: aria-haspopup
props.description: Indicates the availability and type of interactive popup element, such as menu or dialog, that can be triggered by an element.

props.name: aria-hidden
props.description: Indicates whether the element is exposed to an accessibility API.

props.name: aria-invalid
props.description: Indicates the entered value does not conform to the format expected by the application.

props.name: aria-keyshortcuts
props.description: Indicates keyboard shortcuts that an author has implemented to activate or give focus to an element.

props.name: aria-label
props.description: Defines a string value that labels the current element.

props.name: aria-labelledby
props.description: Identifies the element (or elements) that labels the current element.

props.name: aria-level
props.description: Defines the hierarchical level of an element within a structure.

props.name: aria-live
props.description: Indicates that an element will be updated, and describes the types of updates the user agents, assistive technologies, and user can expect from the live region.

props.name: aria-modal
props.description: Indicates whether an element is modal when displayed.

props.name: aria-multiline
props.description: Indicates whether a text box accepts multiple lines of input or only a single line.

props.name: aria-multiselectable
props.description: Indicates that the user may select more than one item from the current selectable descendants.

props.name: aria-orientation
props.description: Indicates whether the element's orientation is horizontal, vertical, or unknown/ambiguous.

props.name: aria-owns
props.description:
Identifies an element (or elements) in order to define a visual, functional, or contextual parent/child relationship
between DOM elements where the DOM hierarchy cannot be used to represent the relationship.

props.name: aria-placeholder
props.description:
Defines a short hint (a word or short phrase) intended to aid the user with data entry when the control has no value.
A hint could be a sample value or a brief description of the expected format.

props.name: aria-posinset
props.description: Defines an element's number or position in the current set of listitems or treeitems. Not required if all elements in the set are present in the DOM.

props.name: aria-pressed
props.description: Indicates the current "pressed" state of toggle buttons.

props.name: aria-readonly
props.description: Indicates that the element is not editable, but is otherwise operable.

props.name: aria-relevant
props.type: "text" | "additions" | "additions removals" | "additions text" | "all" | "removals" | "removals additions" | "removals text" | "text additions" | "text removals"
props.description: Indicates what notifications the user agent will trigger when the accessibility tree within a live region is modified.

props.name: aria-required
props.description: Indicates that user input is required on the element before a form may be submitted.

props.name: aria-roledescription
props.description: Defines a human-readable, author-localized description for the role of an element.

props.name: aria-rowcount
props.description: Defines the total number of rows in a table, grid, or treegrid.

props.name: aria-rowindex
props.description: Defines an element's row index or position with respect to the total number of rows within a table, grid, or treegrid.

props.name: aria-rowspan
props.description: Defines the number of rows spanned by a cell or gridcell within a table, grid, or treegrid.

props.name: aria-selected
props.description: Indicates the current "selected" state of various widgets.

props.name: aria-setsize
props.description: Defines the number of items in the current set of listitems or treeitems. Not required if all elements in the set are present in the DOM.

props.name: aria-sort
props.description: Indicates if items in a table or grid are sorted in ascending or descending order.

props.name: aria-valuemax
props.description: Defines the maximum allowed value for a range widget.

props.description: Defines the minimum allowed value for a range widget.

props.description: Defines the human readable text alternative of aria-valuenow for a range widget.

components.name: picklist
components.title: Vue PickList Component
components.description: PickList is used to reorder items between different lists.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Value to describe the source listbox and target listbox can be provided with sourceListProps and targetListProps by passing aria-labelledby or aria-label props. The list elements has a listbox role with the aria-multiselectable attribute. Each list item has an option role with aria-selected as their attributes. Controls buttons are button elements with an aria-label that refers to the aria.moveTop , aria.moveUp , aria.moveDown , aria.moveBottom , aria.moveToTarget , aria.moveAllToTarget , aria.moveToSource and aria.moveAllToSource properties of the locale API by default, alternatively you may use moveTopButtonProps , moveUpButtonProps , moveDownButtonProps , moveToButtonProps , moveAllToButtonProps , moveFromButtonProps , moveFromButtonProps moveAllFromButtonProps moveToTargetProps , moveAllToTargetProps , moveToSourceProps and moveAllToSourceProps to customize the buttons like overriding the default aria-label attributes. ListBox Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the first selected option, if there is none then first option receives the focus. up arrow Moves focus to the previous option. down arrow Moves focus to the next option. enter Toggles the selected state of the focused option. space Toggles the selected state of the focused option. home Moves focus to the first option. end Moves focus to the last option. shift + down arrow Moves focus to the next option and toggles the selection state. shift + up arrow Moves focus to the previous option and toggles the selection state. shift + space Selects the items between the most recently selected option and the focused option. control + shift + home Selects the focused options and all the options up to the first one. control + shift + end Selects the focused options and all the options down to the first one. control + a Selects all options. Buttons Keyboard Support Key Function enter Executes button action. space Executes button action.

examples.basic: Options

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: PickList requires a multidimensional array as its value bound with the v-model directive and a template for its content that gets the option instance and the index via slotProps.

examples.basic: import PickList from 'primevue/picklist';

sections.label: Template
sections.description: For custom content support define an option template that gets the item instance as a parameter. In addition sourceheader and targetheader slots are provided for further customization.

components.name: popover
components.title: Vue Popover Component
components.description: Popover is a container component that can overlay other components on page.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Popover component uses dialog role and since any attribute is passed to the root element you may define attributes like aria-label or aria-labelledby to describe the popup contents. In addition aria-modal is added since focus is kept within the popup. Popover adds aria-expanded state attribute and aria-controls to the trigger so that the relation between the trigger and the popup is defined. Popover Keyboard Support When the popup gets opened, the first focusable element receives the focus and this can be customized by adding autofocus to an element within the popup. Key Function tab Moves focus to the next the focusable element within the popup. shift + tab Moves focus to the previous the focusable element within the popup. escape Closes the popup and moves focus to the trigger.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Popover is accessed via its ref and visibility is controlled using toggle , show and hide functions with an event of the target.

examples.basic: Team Members

sections.label: DataTable
sections.description: Place the Popover outside of the data iteration components to avoid rendering it multiple times.

examples.basic: import Popover from 'primevue/popover';

sections.label: Select Data
sections.description: In this sample, data is retrieved from the content inside the popover.

props.name: dismissable
props.description: Enables to hide the overlay when outside is clicked.

props.name: appendTo
props.description: A valid query selector or an HTMLElement to specify where the overlay gets attached.

props.name: baseZIndex
props.description: Base zIndex value to use in layering.

props.name: autoZIndex
props.description: Whether to automatically manage layering.

props.name: breakpoints
props.description: Object literal to define widths per screen size.

props.name: dt
props.description: It generates scoped CSS variables using design tokens for the component.

props.name: pt
props.description: Used to pass attributes to DOM elements inside the component.

props.name: ptOptions
props.description: Used to configure passthrough(pt) options of the component.

props.name: unstyled
props.description: When enabled, it removes component related styles in the core.

props.name: closeOnEscape
props.description: Specifies if pressing escape key should hide the dialog.

pt.name: root
pt.description: Used to pass attributes to the root's DOM element.

pt.name: content
pt.description: Used to pass attributes to the content's DOM element.

pt.description: Used to manage all lifecycle hooks.

pt.description: Used to control Vue Transition API.

Class name of the content element

components.name: progressbar
components.title: Vue ProgressBar Component
components.description: ProgressBar is a process status indicator.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader ProgressBar components uses progressbar role along with aria-valuemin , aria-valuemax and aria-valuenow attributes. Value to describe the component can be defined using aria-labelledby and aria-label props. Keyboard Support Not applicable.

examples.basic:
<span id="label_status" />
<ProgressBar aria-labelledby="label_status" />

<ProgressBar aria-label="Status" />

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: ProgressBar is used with the value property.

examples.basic: <ProgressBar :value="50"></ProgressBar>

sections.label: Dynamic
sections.description: Value is reactive so updating it dynamically changes the bar as well.

examples.basic: <ProgressBar :value="value"></ProgressBar>
import ProgressBar from 'primevue/progressbar';

sections.label: Indeterminate
sections.description: For progresses with no value to track, set the mode property to indeterminate .

examples.basic: <ProgressBar mode="indeterminate" style="height: 6px"></ProgressBar>

sections.label: Template
sections.description: Custom content inside the ProgressBar is defined with the default slot.

components.name: progressspinner
components.title: Vue ProgressSpinner Component
components.description: ProgressSpinner is a process status indicator.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader ProgressSpinner components uses progressbar role. Value to describe the component can be defined using aria-labelledby and aria-label props. Keyboard Support Component does not include any interactive elements.

examples.basic: <ProgressSpinner aria-label="Loading" />

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: An infinite spin animation is displayed by default.

examples.basic: <ProgressSpinner />

sections.label: Custom
sections.description: ProgressSpinner can be customized with styling property like style , strokeWidth fill and animationDuration .

examples.basic:
<ProgressSpinner style="width: 50px; height: 50px" strokeWidth="8" fill="transparent"
    animationDuration=".5s" aria-label="Custom ProgressSpinner" />
import ProgressSpinner from 'primevue/progressspinner';

components.name: radiobutton
components.title: Vue RadioButton Component
components.description: RadioButton is an extension to standard radio button element with theming.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader RadioButton component uses a hidden native radio button element internally that is only visible to screen readers. Value to describe the component can either be provided via label tag combined with id prop or using aria-labelledby , aria-label props. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the checked radio button, if there is none within the group then first radio button receives the focus. left arrow up arrow Moves focus to the previous radio button, if there is none then last radio button receives the focus. right arrow down arrow Moves focus to the next radio button, if there is none then first radio button receives the focus. space If the focused radio button is unchecked, changes the state to checked.

examples.basic: Two

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, the element cannot be edited and focused.

examples.basic:
<RadioButton v-model="value" :value="1" disabled />
<RadioButton v-model="value" :value="2" disabled />

sections.label: Dynamic
sections.description: RadioButtons can be generated using a list of values.

sections.label: Filled
sections.description: Specify the variant property as filled to display the component with a higher visual emphasis than the default outlined style.

examples.basic: <RadioButton v-model="value" value="1" variant="filled" />

sections.label: Forms
sections.description: RadioButton integrates seamlessly with the PrimeVue Forms library.

sections.label: Group
sections.description: RadioButton is used with the v-model property for two-way value binding.

examples.basic:
import RadioButton from 'primevue/radiobutton';
import RadioButtonGroup from 'primevue/radiobuttongroup';

sections.label: Invalid
sections.description: Invalid state is displayed using the invalid prop to indicate a failed validation. You can use this style when integrating with form validation libraries.

examples.basic: <RadioButton v-model="value" value="1" :invalid="value === null" />

sections.label: Sizes
sections.description: RadioButton provides small and large sizes as alternatives to the base.

components.name: rating
components.title: Vue Rating Component
components.description: Rating component is a star based selection input.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Rating component internally uses radio buttons that are only visible to screen readers. The value to read for item is retrieved from the locale API via star and stars of the aria property. Keyboard Support Keyboard interaction is derived from the native browser handling of radio buttons in a group. Key Function tab Moves focus to the star representing the value, if there is none then first star receives the focus. left arrow up arrow Moves focus to the previous star, if there is none then last radio button receives the focus. right arrow down arrow Moves focus to the next star, if there is none then first star receives the focus. space If the focused star does not represent the value, changes the value to the star value.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Rating is used with the v-model property for two-way value binding.

examples.basic: <Rating v-model="value" />

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, a visual hint is applied to indicate that the Knob cannot be interacted with.

examples.basic: <Rating v-model="value" disabled />

sections.label: Forms
sections.description: Rating integrates seamlessly with the PrimeVue Forms library.

examples.basic: import Rating from 'primevue/rating';

sections.label: Number of Stars
sections.description: Number of stars to display is defined with stars property.

examples.basic: <Rating v-model="value" :stars="10" />

sections.label: ReadOnly
sections.description: When readOnly present, value cannot be edited.

examples.basic: <Rating v-model="value" readonly />

sections.label: Template
sections.description: Custom icons are used to override the default icons with onicon , officon and cancelicon slots.

components.name: ripple
components.title: Vue Ripple Component
components.description: Ripple directive adds ripple effect to the host element.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Ripple element has the aria-hidden attribute as true so that it gets ignored by the screen readers. Keyboard Support Component does not include any interactive elements.

sections.label: Configuration
sections.description: To start with, Ripple needs to be enabled globally. See the Configuration API for details.

sections.label: Custom
sections.description: Default styling of the animation adds a shade of white. This can easily be customized using css that changes the color of p-ink element.

examples.basic:
Green
Orange
Purple

sections.label: Default
sections.description: Ripple is enabled by adding add p-ripple class to the target and attach the directive with the v- prefix.

examples.basic: Default

sections.label: Import
sections.description: Ripple is an optional animation for the supported components such as buttons. It is disabled by default and needs to be enabled at your app's entry file (e.g. main.js) during the PrimeVue setup. Ripple describes how to use it with your own components and standard elements that needs to be imported and configured with a name of your choice. Global configuration is done with the app.directive function.

components.description: ScrollPanel is a cross browser, lightweight and skinnable alternative to native browser scrollbar.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Scrollbars of the ScrollPanel has a scrollbar role along with the aria-controls attribute that refers to the id of the scrollable content container and the aria-orientation to indicate the orientation of scrolling. Header Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus through the bar. down arrow Scrolls content down when vertical scrolling is available. up arrow Scrolls content up when vertical scrolling is available. left Scrolls content left when horizontal scrolling is available. right Scrolls content right when horizontal scrolling is available.

sections.description: ScrollPanel is defined using dimensions for the scrollable viewport.

components.name: scrolltop

components.description: ScrollTop gets displayed after a certain scroll position and used to navigates to the top of the page quickly.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader ScrollTop uses a button element with an aria-label that refers to the aria.scrollTop property of the locale API by default, you may use your own aria roles and attributes as any valid attribute is passed to the button element implicitly. Keyboard Support Key Function enter Scrolls to top. space Scrolls to top.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: ScrollTop listens window scroll by default.

examples.basic: <ScrollTop />

sections.label: Element
sections.description: Setting the target property to parent binds ScrollTop to its parent element that has scrolling content.

components.name: select
components.title: Vue Select Component
components.description: Select is used to choose an item from a collection of options.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Value to describe the component can either be provided with aria-labelledby or aria-label props. The select element has a combobox role in addition to aria-haspopup and aria-expanded attributes. If the editable option is enabled aria-autocomplete is also added. The relation between the combobox and the popup is created with aria-controls and aria-activedescendant attribute is used to instruct screen reader which option to read during keyboard navigation within the popup list. The popup list has an id that refers to the aria-controls attribute of the combobox element and uses listbox as the role. Each list item has an option role, an id to match the aria-activedescendant of the input element along with aria-label , aria-selected and aria-disabled attributes. If filtering is enabled, filterInputProps can be defined to give aria-* props to the filter input element. Closed State Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the select element. space Opens the popup and moves visual focus to the selected option, if there is none then first option receives the focus. enter Opens the popup and moves visual focus to the selected option, if there is none then first option receives the focus. down arrow Opens the popup and moves visual focus to the selected option, if there is none then first option receives the focus. up arrow Opens the popup and moves visual focus to the selected option, if there is none then last option receives the focus. any printable character Opens the popup and moves focus to the option whose label starts with the characters being typed, if there is none and select is not editable then first option receives the focus. Popup Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the next focusable element in the popup. If there is none, the focusable option is selected and the overlay is closed then moves focus to next element in page. shift + tab Moves focus to the previous focusable element in the popup. If there is none, the focusable option is selected and the overlay is closed then moves focus to next element in page. enter Selects the focused option and closes the popup, then moves focus to the select element. space Selects the focused option and closes the popup, then moves focus to the select element. escape Closes the popup, then moves focus to the select element. down arrow Moves focus to the next option, if there is none then visual focus does not change. up arrow Moves focus to the previous option, if there is none then visual focus does not change. alt + up arrow Selects the focused option and closes the popup, then moves focus to the select element. left arrow If the select is editable, removes the visual focus from the current option and moves input cursor to one character left. right arrow If the select is editable, removes the visual focus from the current option and moves input cursor to one character right. home If the select is editable, moves input cursor at the end, if not then moves focus to the first option. end If the select is editable, moves input cursor at the beginning, if not then moves focus to the last option. pageUp Jumps visual focus to first option. pageDown Jumps visual focus to last option. any printable character Moves focus to the option whose label starts with the characters being typed if select is not editable. Filter Input Keyboard Support Key Function down arrow Moves focus to the next option, if there is none then visual focus does not change. up arrow Moves focus to the previous option, if there is none then visual focus does not change. left arrow Removes the visual focus from the current option and moves input cursor to one character left. right arrow Removes the visual focus from the current option and moves input cursor to one character right. home Moves input cursor at the end, if not then moves focus to the first option. end Moves input cursor at the beginning, if not then moves focus to the last option. enter Closes the popup and moves focus to the select element. escape Closes the popup and moves focus to the select element. tab Moves focus to the next focusable element in the popup. If there is none, the focusable option is selected and the overlay is closed then moves focus to next element in page.

examples.basic: Options

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Select is used with the v-model property for two-way value binding along with the options collection. Label and value of an option are defined with the optionLabel and optionValue properties respectively. Note that, when options are simple primitive values such as a string array, no optionLabel and optionValue would be necessary.

examples.basic: <Select v-model="selectedCity" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" placeholder="Select a City" class="w-full md:w-56" />

sections.label: Checkmark
sections.description: An alternative way to highlight the selected option is displaying a checkmark instead.

examples.basic: <Select v-model="selectedCity" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" placeholder="Select a City" checkmark :highlightOnSelect="false" class="w-full md:w-56" />

sections.label: Clear Icon
sections.description: When showClear is enabled, a clear icon is added to reset the Select.

examples.basic: <Select v-model="selectedCity" :options="cities" showClear optionLabel="name" placeholder="Select a City" class="w-full md:w-56" />

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, the element cannot be edited and focused.

examples.basic: <Select disabled placeholder="Select a City" class="w-full md:w-56" />

sections.label: Editable
sections.description: When editable is present, the input can also be entered with typing.

examples.basic: <Select v-model="selectedCity" editable :options="cities" optionLabel="name" placeholder="Select a City" class="w-full md:w-56" />

sections.label: Filled
sections.description: Specify the variant property as filled to display the component with a higher visual emphasis than the default outlined style.

examples.basic: <Select v-model="selectedCity" variant="filled" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" placeholder="Select a City" class="w-full md:w-56" />

sections.label: Filter
sections.description: Select provides built-in filtering that is enabled by adding the filter property.

sections.label: Float Label
sections.description: A floating label appears on top of the input field when focused. Visit FloatLabel documentation for more information.

examples.basic:
<FloatLabel class="w-full md:w-56">
    <Select v-model="value1" inputId="over_label" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" class="w-full" />
    <label for="over_label">Over Label</label>
</FloatLabel>

<FloatLabel class="w-full md:w-56" variant="in">
    <Select v-model="value2" inputId="in_label" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" class="w-full" variant="filled" />
    <label for="in_label">In Label</label>
</FloatLabel>

<FloatLabel class="w-full md:w-56" variant="on">
    <Select v-model="value3" inputId="on_label" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" class="w-full" />
    <label for="on_label">On Label</label>
</FloatLabel>

sections.label: Fluid
sections.description: The fluid prop makes the component take up the full width of its container when set to true.

examples.basic: <Select v-model="selectedCity" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" placeholder="Select a City" fluid />

sections.label: Group
sections.description: Options can be grouped when a nested data structures is provided. To define the label of a group optionGroupLabel property is needed and also optionGroupChildren is required to define the property that refers to the children of a group.

sections.label: Ifta Label
sections.description: IftaLabel is used to create infield top aligned labels. Visit IftaLabel documentation for more information.

examples.basic:
<IftaLabel>
    <Select v-model="selectedCity" inputId="dd-city" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" class="w-full" variant="filled" />
    <label for="dd-city">City</label>
</IftaLabel>
import Select from 'primevue/select';

sections.label: Invalid
sections.description: Invalid state is displayed using the invalid prop to indicate a failed validation. You can use this style when integrating with form validation libraries.

examples.basic:
<Select v-model="selectedCity1" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" placeholder="Select a City" :invalid="!selectedCity1" class="w-full md:w-56" />
<Select v-model="selectedCity2" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" placeholder="Select a City" :invalid="!selectedCity2" class="w-full md:w-56" variant="filled" />

sections.label: Lazy Virtual Scroll
sections.description: The virtual scrolling also supports dynamically loading items on demand.

examples.basic:
<Select v-model="selectedItem" :options="items" optionLabel="label" optionValue="value" class="w-full md:w-56"
    :virtualScrollerOptions="{ lazy: true, onLazyLoad: onLazyLoad, itemSize: 38, showLoader: true, loading: loading, delay: 250 }" placeholder="Select Item" />

sections.label: Loading State
sections.description: Loading state is enabled with the loading property.

examples.basic: <Select placeholder="Loading..." loading class="w-full md:w-56" />

sections.label: Sizes
sections.description: Select provides small and large sizes as alternatives to the base.

examples.basic:
<Select v-model="value1" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" size="small" placeholder="Small" class="w-full md:w-56" />
<Select v-model="value2" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" placeholder="Normal" class="w-full md:w-56" />
<Select v-model="value3" :options="cities" optionLabel="name" size="large" placeholder="Large" class="w-full md:w-56" />

sections.label: Template
sections.description: Select offers multiple slots for customization through templating.

sections.label: Virtual Scroll
sections.description: VirtualScroller is used to render a long list of options efficiently like 100K records in this demo. The configuration is done with virtualScrollerOptions property, refer to the VirtualScroller for more information about the available options as it is used internally by Select.

examples.basic:
<Select v-model="selectedItem" :options="items" optionLabel="label" optionValue="value"
    :virtualScrollerOptions="{ itemSize: 38 }" placeholder="Select Item" class="w-full md:w-56" />

props.name: modelValue
props.description: Value of the component.

props.name: defaultValue
props.description: The default value for the input when not controlled by  `modelValue` .

props.name: name
props.description: The name attribute for the element, typically used in form submissions.

props.name: options
props.description: An array of select items to display as the available options.

props.name: optionLabel
props.description: Property name or getter function to use as the label of an option.

props.name: optionValue
props.description: Property name or getter function to use as the value of an option, defaults to the option itself when not defined.

props.name: optionDisabled
props.description: Property name or getter function to use as the disabled flag of an option, defaults to false when not defined.

props.name: optionGroupLabel
props.description: Property name or getter function to use as the label of an option group.

props.name: optionGroupChildren
props.description: Property name or getter function that refers to the children options of option group.

props.name: scrollHeight
props.description: Height of the viewport, a scrollbar is defined if height of list exceeds this value.

props.name: filter
props.description: When specified, displays a filter input at header.

props.name: filterPlaceholder
props.description: Placeholder text to show when filter input is empty.

props.name: filterLocale
props.description: Locale to use in filtering. The default locale is the host environment's current locale.

props.name: filterMatchMode
props.description: Defines the filtering algorithm to use when searching the options.

props.name: filterFields
props.description: Fields used when filtering the options, defaults to optionLabel.

props.name: editable
props.description: When present, custom value instead of predefined options can be entered using the editable input field.

props.name: placeholder
props.description: Default text to display when no option is selected.

props.name: size
props.description: Defines the size of the component.

props.name: invalid
props.description: When present, it specifies that the component should have invalid state style.

props.name: disabled
props.description: When present, it specifies that the component should be disabled.

props.name: variant
props.description: Specifies the input variant of the component.

props.name: dataKey
props.description: A property to uniquely identify an option.

props.name: showClear
props.description: When enabled, a clear icon is displayed to clear the value.

props.name: fluid
props.description: Spans 100% width of the container when enabled.

props.name: labelId
props.description: Identifier of the underlying label element.

props.name: labelStyle
props.description: Inline style of the label field.

props.name: labelClass
props.description: Style class of the label field.

props.name: overlayStyle
props.description: Inline style of the overlay.

props.name: overlayClass
props.description: Style class of the overlay.

props.name: appendTo
props.description: A valid query selector or an HTMLElement to specify where the overlay gets attached.

props.name: loading
props.description: Whether the select is in loading state.

props.name: clearIcon
props.description: Icon to display in clear button.

props.name: dropdownIcon
props.description: Icon to display in the select.

props.name: filterIcon
props.description: Icon to display in filter input.

props.name: loadingIcon
props.description: Icon to display in loading state.

props.name: resetFilterOnHide
props.description: Clears the filter value when hiding the select.

props.name: resetFilterOnClear
props.description: Clears the filter value when clicking on the clear icon.

props.name: virtualScrollerOptions
props.description: Whether to use the virtualScroller feature. The properties of VirtualScroller component can be used like an object in it.

props.name: autoOptionFocus
props.description: Whether to focus on the first visible or selected element when the overlay panel is shown.

props.name: autoFilterFocus
props.description: Whether to focus on the filter element when the overlay panel is shown.

props.name: selectOnFocus
props.description: When enabled, the focused option is selected.

props.name: focusOnHover
props.description: When enabled, the focus is placed on the hovered option.

props.name: highlightOnSelect
props.description: Whether the selected option will be add highlight class.

props.name: checkmark
props.description: Whether the selected option will be shown with a check mark.

props.name: filterMessage
props.description: Text to be displayed in hidden accessible field when filtering returns any results. Defaults to value from PrimeVue locale configuration.

props.name: selectionMessage
props.description: Text to be displayed in hidden accessible field when options are selected. Defaults to value from PrimeVue locale configuration.

props.name: emptySelectionMessage
props.description: Text to be displayed in hidden accessible field when any option is not selected. Defaults to value from PrimeVue locale configuration.

props.name: emptyFilterMessage
props.description: Text to display when filtering does not return any results. Defaults to value from PrimeVue locale configuration.

props.name: emptyMessage
props.description: Text to display when there are no options available. Defaults to value from PrimeVue locale configuration.

props.name: tabindex
props.description: Index of the element in tabbing order.

props.name: ariaLabel
props.description: Defines a string value that labels an interactive element.

props.name: ariaLabelledby
props.description: Identifier of the underlying input element.

props.name: formControl
props.description: Form control object, typically used for handling validation and form state.

props.description: It generates scoped CSS variables using design tokens for the component.

props.description: Used to pass attributes to DOM elements inside the component.

props.description: Used to configure passthrough(pt) options of the component.

props.name: unstyled
props.description: When enabled, it removes component related styles in the core.

components.name: selectbutton
components.title: Vue SelectButton Component
components.description: SelectButton is used to choose single or multiple items from a list using buttons.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader SelectButton component uses ToggleButton internally and has group role. Value to describe the component can be provided via aria-labelledby property. Keyboard Support Keyboard interaction is derived from the native browser handling of checkboxs in a group. Key Function tab Moves focus to the next the focusable element in the page tab sequence. shift + tab Moves focus to the previous the focusable element in the page tab sequence. space Toggles the checked state of a button.

examples.basic: Number

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: SelectButton is used with the v-model property for two-way value binding along with the options collection. Label and value of an option are defined with the optionLabel and optionValue properties respectively. Note that, when options are simple primitive values such as a string array, no optionLabel and optionValue would be necessary.

examples.basic: <SelectButton v-model="value" :options="options" />

sections.label: Disabled
sections.description: When disabled is present, the element cannot be edited and focused entirely. Certain options can also be disabled using the optionDisabled property.

examples.basic:
<SelectButton v-model="value" :options="options" disabled />
<SelectButton v-model="value" :options="options2" optionDisabled="constant" optionLabel="name" />

sections.label: Fluid
sections.description: The fluid prop makes the component take up the full width of its container when set to true.

examples.basic: <SelectButton v-model="value" :options="options" fluid />

sections.label: Forms
sections.description: SelectButton integrates seamlessly with the PrimeVue Forms library.

examples.basic: import SelectButton from 'primevue/selectbutton';

sections.label: Invalid
sections.description: Invalid state is displayed using the invalid prop to indicate a failed validation. You can use this style when integrating with form validation libraries.

examples.basic: <SelectButton v-model="value" :options="options" aria-labelledby="basic" allowEmpty :invalid="value === null"  />

sections.label: Multiple
sections.description: SelectButton allows selecting only one item by default and setting multiple option enables choosing more than one item. In multiple case, model property should be an array.

examples.basic: <SelectButton v-model="value" :options="options" optionLabel="name" multiple aria-labelledby="multiple" />

sections.label: Sizes
sections.description: SelectButton provides small and large sizes as alternatives to the base.

examples.basic:
<SelectButton v-model="value1" :options="options" size="small" />
<SelectButton v-model="value2" :options="options" />
<SelectButton v-model="value3" :options="options" size="large" />

sections.label: Template
sections.description: Label of an option is used as the display text of an item by default, for custom content support define an option template that gets the option instance as a parameter.

components.name: skeleton
components.title: Vue Skeleton Component
components.description: Skeleton is a placeholder to display instead of the actual content.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Skeleton uses aria-hidden as "true" so that it gets ignored by screen readers, any valid attribute is passed to the root element so you may customize it further if required. If multiple skeletons are grouped inside a container, you may use aria-busy on the container element as well to indicate the loading process. Keyboard Support Component does not include any interactive elements.

sections.label: Card
sections.description: Sample card implementation using different Skeleton components and Tailwind CSS utilities.

sections.label: DataTable
sections.description: Sample DataTable implementation using different Skeleton components and Tailwind CSS utilities.

examples.basic:
<DataTable :value="products">
    <Column field="code" header="Code">
        <template #body>
            <Skeleton></Skeleton>
        </template>
    </Column>
    <Column field="name" header="Name">
        <template #body>
            <Skeleton></Skeleton>
        </template>
    </Column>
    <Column field="category" header="Category">
        <template #body>
            <Skeleton></Skeleton>
        </template>
    </Column>
    <Column field="quantity" header="Quantity">
        <template #body>
            <Skeleton></Skeleton>
        </template>
    </Column>
</DataTable>
import Skeleton from 'primevue/skeleton';

sections.label: List
sections.description: Sample list implementation using different Skeleton components and Tailwind CSS utilities.

sections.label: Shapes
sections.description: Various shapes and sizes can be created using styling properties like shape , width , height , borderRadius and class .

examples.basic:
Rectangle
Rounded
Square
Circle

props.name: width

props.name: height

props.name: borderRadius
props.description: Border radius of the element, defaults to value from theme.

components.name: slider
components.title: Vue Slider Component
components.description: Slider is a component to provide input with a drag handle.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Slider element component uses slider role on the handle in addition to the aria-orientation , aria-valuemin , aria-valuemax and aria-valuenow attributes. Value to describe the component can be defined using aria-labelledby and aria-label props. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus to the slider. left arrow up arrow Decrements the value. right arrow down arrow Increments the value. home Set the minimum value. end Set the maximum value. page up Increments the value by 10 steps. page down Decrements the value by 10 steps.

examples.basic: Number

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Slider is used with the v-model property for two-way value binding.

examples.basic: <Slider v-model="value" class="w-56" />

sections.label: Filter
sections.description: Image filter implementation using multiple sliders.

sections.label: Forms
sections.description: Slider integrates seamlessly with the PrimeVue Forms library.

examples.basic: import Slider from 'primevue/slider';

sections.label: Input
sections.description: Slider is connected to an input field using two-way binding.

examples.basic:
<InputText v-model.number="value" />
<Slider v-model="value" />

sections.label: Range
sections.description: When range property is present, slider provides two handles to define two values. In range mode, value should be an array instead of a single value.

examples.basic: <Slider v-model="value" range class="w-56" />

sections.label: Step
sections.description: Size of each movement is defined with the step property.

examples.basic: <Slider v-model="value" :step="20" class="w-56" />

sections.label: Vertical
sections.description: Default layout of slider is horizontal , use orientation property for the alternative vertical mode.

examples.basic: <Slider v-model="value" orientation="vertical" class="h-56" />

components.name: speeddial
components.title: Vue Speed Dial Component
components.description: When pressed, a floating action button can display multiple primary actions that can be performed on a page.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader SpeedDial component renders a native button element that implicitly includes any passed prop. Text to describe the button can be defined with the aria-labelledby or aria-label props. Addititonally the button includes includes aria-haspopup , aria-expanded for states along with aria-controls to define the relation between the popup and the button. The popup overlay uses menu role on the list and each action item has a menuitem role with an aria-label as the menuitem label. The id of the menu refers to the aria-controls of the button. Menu Button Keyboard Support Key Function enter Toggles the visibility of the menu. space Toggles the visibility of the menu. down arrow Opens the menu and moves focus to the first item. up arrow Opens the menu and moves focus to the last item. right arrow Opens the menu and moves focus to the last item. left arrow Opens the menu and moves focus to the first item. escape Closes the menu. Menu Keyboard Support Key Function enter Actives the menuitem, closes the menu and sets focus on the menu button. space Actives the menuitem, closes the menu and sets focus on the menu button. escape Closes the menu and sets focus on the menu button. arrow keys Navigates between the menu items. home Moves focus to the first item. end Moves focus to the last item.

examples.basic: <SpeedDial aria-label="Options" />

sections.label: Circle
sections.description: Items can be displayed around the button when type is set to circle . Additional radius property defines the radius of the circle.

examples.basic: <SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="80" type="circle" :style="{ position: 'absolute' }" :buttonProps="{ severity: 'warn', rounded: true }" />
import SpeedDial from 'primevue/speeddial';

sections.label: Linear
sections.description: SpeedDial items are defined with the model property based on MenuModel API. Default orientation of the items is linear and direction property is used to define the position of the items related to the button.

examples.basic:
<SpeedDial :model="items" direction="up" style="position: absolute; left: calc(50% - 2rem); bottom: 0" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" direction="down" style="position: absolute; left: calc(50% - 2rem); top: 0" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" direction="left" style="position: absolute; top: calc(50% - 2rem); right: 0" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" direction="right" style="position: absolute; top: calc(50% - 2rem); left: 0" />

sections.label: Mask
sections.description: Adding mask property displays a modal layer behind the popup items.

examples.basic: <SpeedDial :model="items" direction="up" mask :style="{ position: 'absolute', right: '1rem', bottom: '1rem' }" />

sections.label: QuarterCircleDoc
sections.description: Setting type as quarter-circle displays the items at one of four corners of a button based on the direction .

examples.basic:
<SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="120" type="quarter-circle" direction="up-left" :style="{ position: 'absolute', right: 0, bottom: 0 }" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="120" type="quarter-circle" direction="up-right" :style="{ position: 'absolute', left: 0, bottom: 0 }" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="120" type="quarter-circle" direction="down-left" :style="{ position: 'absolute', right: 0, top: 0 }" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="120" type="quarter-circle" direction="down-right" :style="{ position: 'absolute', left: 0, top: 0 }" />

sections.label: SemiCircleDoc
sections.description: When type is defined as semi-circle , items are displayed in a half-circle around the button.

examples.basic:
<SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="80" type="semi-circle" direction="up" style="position: absolute; left: calc(50% - 2rem); bottom: 0" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="80" type="semi-circle" direction="down" style="position: absolute; left: calc(50% - 2rem); top: 0" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="80" type="semi-circle" direction="left" style="position: absolute; top: calc(50% - 2rem); right: 0" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" :radius="80" type="semi-circle" direction="right" style="position: absolute; top: calc(50% - 2rem); left: 0" />

sections.label: Template
sections.description: SpeedDial offers item customization with the item template that receives the menuitem instance from the model as a parameter. The button has its own button template, additional slot named icon is provided to embed icon content for default button.

sections.label: Tooltip
sections.description: Items display a tooltip on hover when a standalone Tooltip is present with a target that matches the items.

examples.basic:
<SpeedDial :model="items" direction="up" :style="{ position: 'absolute', right: 0, bottom: 0 }" :buttonProps="{ severity: 'help', rounded: true }" :tooltipOptions="{ position: 'left' }" />
<SpeedDial :model="items" direction="up" :style="{ position: 'absolute', left: 0, bottom: 0 }" :buttonProps="{ severity: 'danger', rounded: true }" :tooltipOptions="{ position: 'right' }" />

components.name: splitbutton
components.title: Vue SplitButton Component
components.description: SplitButton groups a set of commands in an overlay with a default command.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader SplitButton component renders two native button elements, main button uses the label property to define aria-label by default which can be customized with buttonProps . Dropdown button requires an explicit definition to describe it using menuButtonProps option and also includes aria-haspopup , aria-expanded for states along with aria-controls to define the relation between the popup and the button. The popup overlay uses menu role on the list and each action item has a menuitem role with an aria-label as the menuitem label. The id of the menu refers to the aria-controls of the dropdown button. Main Button Keyboard Support Key Function enter Activates the button. space Activates the button. Menu Button Keyboard Support Key Function enter space down arrow up arrow Opens the menu and moves focus to the first item. Menu Keyboard Support Key Function enter If menuitem has a submenu, opens the submenu otherwise activates the menuitem and closes all open overlays. space If menuitem has a submenu, opens the submenu otherwise activates the menuitem and closes all open overlays. escape If focus is inside a popup submenu, closes the submenu and moves focus to the root item of the closed submenu. down arrow Moves focus to the next menuitem within the submenu. up arrow Moves focus to the previous menuitem within the submenu. alt + up arrow Closes the popup, then moves focus to the target element. right arrow In nested mode if option is closed, opens the option otherwise moves focus to the first child option. left arrow In nested mode if option is open, closes the option otherwise moves focus to the parent option. home Moves focus to the first menuitem within the submenu. end Moves focus to the last menuitem within the submenu. any printable character Moves focus to the menuitem whose label starts with the characters being typed.

examples.basic: <SplitButton :buttonProps="{'aria-label': 'Default Action'}" :menuButtonProps="{'aria-label': 'More Options'}" />

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: SplitButton has a default command button and a collection of additional options defined by the model property.

components.name: splitter
components.title: Vue Splitter Component
components.description: Splitter is utilized to separate and resize panels.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Splitter bar defines separator as the role with aria-orientation set to either horizontal or vertical. Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus through the splitter bar. down arrow Moves a vertical splitter down. up arrow Moves a vertical splitter up. left arrow Moves a horizontal splitter to the left. right arrow Moves a horizontal splitter to the right.

sections.label: Horizontal
sections.description: Splitter requires two SplitterPanel components as children which are displayed horizontally by default.

examples.basic:
<Splitter style="height: 300px">
    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center"> Panel 1 </SplitterPanel>
    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center"> Panel 2 </SplitterPanel>
</Splitter>

import Splitter from 'primevue/splitter';
import SplitterPanel from 'primevue/splitterpanel';

sections.label: Nested
sections.description: Splitters can be combined to create advanced layouts.

examples.basic:
<Splitter style="height: 300px">
    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center" :size="20" :minSize="10"> Panel 1 </SplitterPanel>
    <SplitterPanel :size="80">
        <Splitter layout="vertical">
            <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center" :size="15"> Panel 2 </SplitterPanel>
            <SplitterPanel :size="85">
                <Splitter>
                    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center" :size="20"> Panel 3 </SplitterPanel>
                    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center" :size="80"> Panel 4 </SplitterPanel>
                </Splitter>
            </SplitterPanel>
        </Splitter>
    </SplitterPanel>
</Splitter>

sections.label: Size
sections.description: Initial dimension of a panel is percentage based and defined using the size property. In addition, minSize is provided to set a minimum value during a resize.

examples.basic:
<Splitter style="height: 300px">
    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center" :size="25" :minSize="10"> Panel 1 </SplitterPanel>
    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center" :size="75"> Panel 2 </SplitterPanel>
</Splitter>

sections.label: Vertical
sections.description: Panels are displayed as stacked by setting the layout to vertical .

examples.basic:
<Splitter style="height: 300px" layout="vertical">
    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center"> Panel 1 </SplitterPanel>
    <SplitterPanel class="flex items-center justify-center"> Panel 2 </SplitterPanel>
</Splitter>

props.name: layout
props.description: Orientation of the panels.

props.name: gutterSize
props.description: Size of the divider in pixels.

props.name: stateKey
props.description: Storage identifier of a stateful Splitter.

props.name: stateStorage
props.description: Defines where a stateful splitter keeps its state, valid values are 'session' for sessionStorage and 'local' for localStorage.

props.name: step
props.description: Step factor to increment/decrement the size of the panels while pressing the arrow keys.

props.name: dt
props.description: It generates scoped CSS variables using design tokens for the component.

props.name: pt
props.description: Used to pass attributes to DOM elements inside the component.

props.name: ptOptions
props.description: Used to configure passthrough(pt) options of the component.

props.name: unstyled
props.description: When enabled, it removes component related styles in the core.

pt.name: root
pt.description: Used to pass attributes to the root's DOM element.

pt.name: gutter
pt.description: Used to pass attributes to the gutter's DOM element.

pt.name: gutterHandle
pt.description: Used to pass attributes to the gutter handle's DOM element.

pt.name: hooks
pt.description: Used to manage all lifecycle hooks.

styles.description: Class name of the root element
Class name of the gutter element
Class name of the gutter handle element

components.name: stepper
components.title: Vue Stepper Component
components.description: The Stepper component displays a wizard-like workflow by guiding users through the multi-step progression.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Stepper container is defined with the tablist role, as any attribute is passed to the container element aria-labelledby can be optionally used to specify an element to describe the Stepper. Each stepper header has a tab role and aria-controls to refer to the corresponding stepper content element. The content element of each stepper has tabpanel role, an id to match the aria-controls of the header and aria-labelledby reference to the header as the accessible name. Tab Header Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus through the header. enter Activates the focused stepper header. space Activates the focused stepper header.

sections.label: Horizontal
sections.description: Stepper consists of a combination of StepList , Step , StepPanels and StepPanel components. The value property is essential for associating Step and StepPanel with each other.

examples.basic:
Header I Header II Header III
Content I
Content II
Content III

sections.label: Linear
sections.description: When linear property is present, current step must be completed in order to move to the next step.

examples.basic:
Header I Header II Header III
Content I
Content II
Content III

sections.label: Steps Only
sections.description: Use Stepper with a StepList only for custom requirements where a progress indicator is needed.

examples.basic:
<Stepper value="1" class="basis-[50rem]">
    <StepList>
        <Step value="1">Design</Step>
        <Step value="2">Development</Step>
        <Step value="3">QA</Step>
    </StepList>
</Stepper>

sections.label: Template
sections.description: Custom content for a step is defined with the default slot. The optional as property controls the default container element of a step, for example setting it to a button renders a button for the header instead of a div. The asChild option enables the headless mode for further customization by passing callbacks and properties to implement your own step.

examples.basic:
Create your account
Choose your interests
Account created successfully

sections.label: Vertical
sections.description: Vertical layout requires StepItem as a wrapper of Step and StepPanel components.

examples.basic:
Header I
Content I
 Header II
Content II
 Header III
Content III

props.description: Active value of stepper.

props.name: linear
props.description: Whether the steps are clickable or not.

props.name: dt
props.description: It generates scoped CSS variables using design tokens for the component.

props.name: pt
props.description: Used to pass attributes to DOM elements inside the component.

props.name: ptOptions
props.description: Used to configure passthrough(pt) options of the component.

props.name: unstyled
props.description: When enabled, it removes component related styles in the core.

pt.name: root

pt.description: Used to pass attributes to the separator's DOM element.

Class name of the separator element

components.name: styleclass
components.title: Vue StyleClass Directive
components.description: StyleClass manages css classes declaratively to during enter/leave animations or just to toggle classes on an element.

sections.label: Animation
sections.description: Classes to apply during enter and leave animations are specified using the enterFromClass , enterActiveClass , enterToClass , leaveFromClass , leaveActiveClass , leaveToClass properties. In addition in case the target is an overlay, hideOnOutsideClick would be handy to hide the target if outside of the popup is clicked. First example uses a custom fade animation, and second one uses animate-slide from tailwind-primeui plugin.

examples.basic:
Custom
Content

sections.label: HideOnResizeDoc
sections.description: When hideOnResize is enabled, the leave animation is triggered automatically when resizing occurs. Use the resizeSelector property to specify whether to listen to window resize events or element-specific resize events. Set resizeSelector to "window" (default) or "document" for browser resize, or a CSS selector to observe the target element's dimensions.

examples.basic:
import StyleClass from 'primevue/styleclass';

app.directive('styleclass', StyleClass);

sections.label: ToggleClassDoc
sections.description: StyleClass has two modes, toggleClass to simply add-remove a class and enter/leave animations.

examples.basic:
<Button v-styleclass="{ selector: '@next', toggleClass: 'p-disabled' }" label="Toggle p-disabled" />
<InputText />

components.name: tabs
components.title: Vue Tabs Component
components.description: Tabs facilitates seamless switching between different views.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader The tabs container in TabList is defined with the tablist role, as any attribute is passed to the container element aria-labelledby can be optionally used to specify an element to describe the Tabs. Each Tab has a tab role along with aria-selected state attribute and aria-controls to refer to the corresponding TabPanel. TabPanel has tabpanel role, an id to match the aria-controls of Tab and aria-labelledby reference to Tab as the accessible name. Tab Keyboard Support Key Function tab Moves focus through the header. enter Activates the focused tab header. space Activates the focused tab header. right arrow Moves focus to the next header. If focus is on the last header, moves focus to the first header. left arrow Moves focus to the previous header. If focus is on the first header, moves focus to the last header. home Moves focus to the last header. end Moves focus to the first header. pageUp Moves scroll position to first header. pageDown Moves scroll position to last header.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Tabs is defined using TabList , Tab , TabPanels and TabPanel components. Tab and TabPanel components are associated with their value properties.

components.name: tag
components.title: Vue Tag Component
components.description: Tag component is used to categorize content.

sections.label: Accessibility
sections.description: Screen Reader Tag does not include any roles and attributes by default, any attribute is passed to the root element so aria roles and attributes can be added if required. If the tags are dynamic, aria-live may be utilized as well. In case badges need to be tabbable, tabindex can be added to implement custom key handlers. Keyboard Support Component does not include any interactive elements.

sections.label: Basic
sections.description: Label of the tag is defined with the value property.

examples.basic: <Tag value="New"></Tag>

sections.label: IconDoc
sections.description: A font icon next to the value can be displayed with the icon property.

examples.basic:
<Tag icon="pi pi-user" value="Primary"></Tag>
<Tag icon="pi pi-search" severity="secondary" value="Secondary"></Tag>
<Tag icon="pi pi-check" severity="success" value="Success"></Tag>
<Tag icon="pi pi-info-circle" severity="info" value="Info"></Tag>
<Tag icon="pi pi-exclamation-triangle" severity="warn" value="Warn"></Tag>
<Tag icon="pi pi-times" severity="danger" value="Danger"></Tag>
<Tag icon="pi pi-cog" severity="contrast" value="Contrast"></Tag>
import Tag from 'primevue/tag';

<Tag severity="danger" value="Danger" rounded></Tag>
<Tag severity="contrast" value="Contrast" rounded></Tag>
